'''Valentin Vasiliyevich Bondarenko''' ({{lang-uk|Валентин Васильович Бондаренко}}, {{lang-ru|Валентин Васильевич Бондаренко}}, 16 February 1937 – 23 March 1961) was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[fighter pilot]] selected in 1960 for training as a [[Astronaut|cosmonaut]]. He died as the result of burns sustained in a fire during a 15-day low-pressure endurance experiment in [[Moscow]]. The government concealed the death, along with Bondarenko's membership in the cosmonaut corps, until 1980. A [[Bondarenko (crater)|crater]] on the [[Far side of the Moon|Moon's far side]] is named after him.
==Education and military training== Bondarenko was born in [[Kharkiv]], [[Ukrainian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]]. His father was sent to the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] in the first days of [[World War II]]. The youngster and his mother went through several years of hardship during the war.
From an early age, Bondarenko was fascinated by aviation heroes and dreamed of becoming a military aviator himself. While still at Kharkiv's Higher Air Force School, he was a member of the local aviation club.<ref name="burgess">{{cite book|last=Burgess|first=Colin|author2=Rex Hall |title=The first Soviet cosmonaut team: their lives, legacy, and historical impact|publisher=Springer|location=Germany|year=2009|pages=35–37|isbn=978-0-387-84823-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rrdVPtCNL9AC&printsec=frontcover&dq=the+first+soviet+cosmonaut+team&ei=fClJS4mAIJC-zgSS-NSNDg&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false|accessdate=2010-01-10}}</ref><ref name="spacefact">[http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/cosmonauts/english/bondarenko_valentin.htm Space Facts website]</ref> After Bondarenko's graduation in 1954 he was admitted to the [[Soviet military academies#Voroshilov Military Academy of the USSR Army General Staff|Voroshilov Aviation Military Academy]] and a year later he was transferred to an air force college in Grozny, Armavir Military Pilot Aviation School, from which he graduated in 1957. In 1956 he married Galina Semenovna Rykova, a medical worker. Their first child was born later that year. During 1956, Bondarenko was sent to Armavir Higher Air Force Pilots School, graduating in 1957—the same year [[Sputnik 1]] was launched.<ref name="burgess" />
Bondarenko was commissioned a Second Lieutenant<ref name="spacefact" /> and served in the [[Soviet Air Force]]'s PribVO (the former [[Baltic Military District]])
==Selection for cosmonaut training== On 28 April 1960, Bondarenko was chosen to be among the first group of 20 cosmonauts. Bondarenko, "(also known as 'Valentin Junior' and 'Tinkerbell') was the youngest member of the cosmonaut team."<ref>Clark, Phillip, "The Soviet Manned Space Program", Salamander Books Limited / Orion Books, a division of Crown Publishers, Inc., New York, 1988, Library of Congress card number 88-1551, ISBN 0-517-56954-X, page 18.</ref> He began training on 31 May for a planned launch on the manned [[Vostok (spacecraft)|Vostok spacecraft]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2014}} According to his fellow cosmonauts, Bondarenko was a mild-mannered person with a pleasant disposition. He had a good singing voice and played tennis well.<ref name="burgess" />
==Death== 23 March 1961 was the tenth day of a 15-day endurance experiment in a low pressure altitude chamber at the [[Institute of Biomedical Problems]] in Moscow.<ref name="kron">[http://www.astronautix.com/astros/bonrenko.htm "Bondarenko Chronology"], ''Encyclopedia Astronautica''</ref> The chamber's atmosphere was at least 50% oxygen. Bondarenko, having completed work for the day, removed some monitoring biosensors from his body and washed his skin with an alcohol-soaked [[Cotton pad|cotton ball]], which he then carelessly threw away. The cotton ball landed on an electric [[hot plate]] which he was using to brew a cup of tea. The cotton ignited and Bondarenko tried to smother the flames with the sleeve of his [[wool]]en coveralls, which caught on fire in the chamber's oxygen-rich atmosphere.
Because of the pressure difference, it took a watching doctor nearly half an hour to open the chamber door. Bondarenko's clothing burned until almost all the oxygen in the chamber was used up and he had suffered [[third-degree burn]]s over most of his body. The attending physician at Botkin Hospital, surgeon and traumatologist Vladimir Golyakhovsky, recalled in 1984 that while attempting to start an [[Intravenous therapy|intravenous drip]], the only blood vessels he could find for inserting a needle were on the [[Sole (foot)|soles]] of Bondarenko's feet, where his flight boots had warded off the flames. According to Golyakhovsky, cosmonaut [[Yuri Gagarin]] spent several hours at the hospital as "deathwatch officer" and Bondarenko died of shock 16 hours after the accident, less than three weeks before Gagarin's historic [[Vostok 1]] first spaceflight.<ref name="oberg">Oberg, James, [http://www.jamesoberg.com/usd10.html ''Uncovering Soviet Disasters''], Chapter 10: "Dead Cosmonauts", pp 156-176, Random House, New York, 1988, retrieved 8 January 2008</ref> Manned orbital flight program director [[Nikolai Kamanin]] blamed Bondarenko's death on the Institute's poor organisation and control of the experiment.<ref name="kron" />
Bondarenko was buried in Lipovaya Roshcha in Kharkiv,<ref name="burgess_1">Burgess, Colin, ''Fallen Astronauts: Heroes Who Died Reaching for the Moon'', page 163, Bison Books, 2003</ref> where his parents were then living. On 17 June 1961 the [[Presidium of the Supreme Soviet]] posthumously awarded Bondarenko the [[Order of the Red Star]].
==Aftermath== News of Bondarenko's accident and death was not published at the time. Bondarenko had already appeared in group films and photos of the first cosmonaut group, and his unexplained disappearance sparked [[Lost Cosmonauts|rumours of cosmonauts dying in failed launches]]. In 1980 the details of this incident were at last published in the West, and in 1986 ''[[Izvestia]]'' published an article by science writer [[Yaroslav Golovanov]], detailing the incident for Soviet readers.<ref name=siddiqi2000>{{cite book | last = Siddiqi | first = Asif A | url = http://history.nasa.gov/printFriendly/series95.html | title = Challenge To Apollo: The Soviet Union and the Space Race, 1945–1974 | publisher = [[NASA]] | pages =266}}</ref>
[[James Oberg]], in his book ''Red Star in Orbit'', wrote how the Soviet government [[Censorship of images in the Soviet Union|airbrushed out the cosmonaut's image]] from an official 1961 photograph of the first six cosmonauts selected for training, while British researcher Rex Hall showed that five people had been erased from an earlier group photograph of 16 cosmonauts. Clumsy attempts were later made to further doctor the historic photographs, with the insertion of imaginative but nonexistent photo details to account for the absence of the original members of the group.<ref name="oberg" />
Bondarenko's death was caused by fire in a sealed, high-oxygen environment, which also befell the crew of ''[[Apollo 1]]''. There was some later unfounded speculation that, had the Soviets been open about the circumstances of Bondarenko's death, [[NASA]] might have been alerted to the hazardous design of the early Apollo command module and would have made changes which could have prevented the 1967 deaths of the three ''Apollo 1'' crew members.<ref>Charles, John, [http://www.thespacereview.com/article/797/1 "Could the CIA have prevented the Apollo 1 fire?]", ''Space Review,'' 29 January 2007, retrieved 5 January 2008</ref> However, by 1966 the lethal hazards of a high-pressure 100-percent-oxygen environment such as Apollo 1's had been thoroughly described in American scientific publications and were well known to NASA.<ref>NASA History, ''[http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4204/ch18-2.html SP-4204, Predictions of Trouble]''</ref>
==Books== An account of Bondarenko's life appears in the 2003 book ''Fallen Astronauts: Heroes Who Died Reaching for the Moon'' by [[Colin Burgess (author)|Colin Burgess]].
